utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Katie Pavlich, Geraldo Rivera, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” President Trump ready to throw down with Democrats as major holes emerge in the whistleblower's complaint.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: We're at war. These people are sick. They're sick. And nobody has called it out like I do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trump willing to go scorched earth over what he's calling the witch-hunt 2.0. It comes as GOP leaders are demanding to know the whistleblower's White House sources as inconsistencies pile up. These new details not stopping Nancy Pelosi from accusing the White House of a cover- up, and floating a new Russian conspiracy theory.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: Two wrongs do not make a right. And the president is going to have to answer that. And they know how wrong it is. So, it's wrong for -- as we saw with the Russian interference. And by the way, I think Russia has a hand in this, by the way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the media is again taking cues from the Democrats pushing this new talking point.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This is how a mafia boss talks.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The entire White House is being run by a person who, like a mob boss.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: That sounds a lot like a mob boss.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: He said this was classic mafia style talk.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Reading a transcript out from a mob wire tapped.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You see mob bosses doing it?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I don't like these mafia-like tactics.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Donald Trump speaks like a mobster.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Greg, I just want to touch on the mafia line, because in most industries you try to differentiate yourself between your competitors because these people are all competing against each other. Yet, they all say the same thing. No originality. Why is that?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: And, also, this isn't new. They were doing this two -- I think, two years ago we have done a similar montage of the mafia smear. But the funniest thing about it is, it's really not a smear, because the reason why Trump is often effective with world leaders is because he is like a mafia boss. The fact is, if you want to negotiator would you rather have Don Corleone than Donnie Osmond. I would rather have -- I mean, who would you rather have? A mafia Don or like a greeter from Lowe's, which is what Joe Biden is.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, HOST
utterances.utterance: As long as he doesn't break the law.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. But that's -- that's a good point. They're basing this mafia thing on things he said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's like -- remember, he's going to shoot somebody. What is --- Donald Trump is basically a dove who talks loud, right? He's pulling troops out. The thing that really bugs me, though, it's still -- this complaint that they're actually preferring this complaint over the actual transcript. And I think it was -- who's the dude that talks like this? Brit Hume. Brit Hume made a great point. He said --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That dude.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- America knows more from the transcript than anybody knows from the actual complaint. And preferring the complaint over the transcript is like, you know, preferring to go to a Super Bowl party than the actual Super Bowl. It's like preferring a stuffed animal over a real one. It's like tofu over steak.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Amazing analogy, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. But I would like to finish this up --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You're making me hungry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. There's only one conclusion, this is orchestrated. It's been going on for three years. They're rejecting a transcript over hearsay. They're blaming Trump for heightened security on transcripts after multiple leaks, essentially, blaming him for buying a better safe. And now you have 300 officials, right? Three hundred officials suddenly come out and they're all mostly Obama officials. So, if this isn't -- this is more orchestrated than the moon landing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And so -- whoa, wow, breaking news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We know that's fake.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Have you seen it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're going to save that discussion for another time. And now they've subpoenaed the secretary of state. What's going on now, Dana?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Right. So, whether it is orchestrated or whatever, when you -- because the way our government is, if you have somebody saying, for example, Rudy Giuliani saying I got all the text messages and they're right here. And they're from the state department. Well then, you have now -- OK, well, we'd like -- we love to have you come up and we'd love to see that. And who are the text messages from? Say they're from five people. So then, the tentacles of this reach out -- and then so many people have to hire lawyers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, the lawyers are the worst.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hope you didn't text me.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I'm a lawyer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No offense, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do know what you mean, though, because now it's spiraling out of control. I'm wondering, Geraldo, if people in the White House think maybe we shouldn't have released the transcript because that just gave him more ammunition. They could have held it back on privileged grounds and said none of your business, and never set the precedent.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I'm not so sure it's spiraling out of control. I challenge your premise there. I think that -- like, for instance, what is the high crime or misdemeanor that the president committed?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I agree. I don't see --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- but the Democrats don't care about that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Even with the allegations as stated. I've read this thing over and over. I mean, there's no high crime or misdemeanor there. So what is the --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a political determination. So, like, I can say that Jesse wearing white tennis shoes with no socks, that's a high crime and misdemeanor because it's a political definition. It's not a legal one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a fashion crime.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: This is all second-hand smoke. These are not whistleblowers. This is one highly paid, highly connected media-type, who may or may not have been a CIA guy at some point in his life. He's the one who's taking the information from all different people in the White House, including the west wing filled with the vipers and snakes and back stabbers and rats. You know, I think that you have a situation here where the president is still -- this is the Russia collusion, illusion, delusion 2.0.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: With that said, and maybe there aren't any high crimes and misdemeanors because I haven't seen any, but the Democrats don't care. They're still gonna do the impeachment. I bet they do it in the House and they vote, and doesn't matter if all the facts are on the president's side. You can't convince them, so this thing --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But that's the issue with the transcript, right? I mean, if they had released the complaint that the intelligence committee in the Senate and the House received without the transcript, people would believe the complaint over the transcript. So, you release the transcript and hope that people can look at it and know exactly what was said. But the timing here now comes into question because the complaint is dated August 12th, 2019. And Adam Schiff claims that he only got it like this week. And you had Alyssa Fonic who sits on the same committee in the House saying yesterday not only should he not be making stuff up, but today pointing out that -- how long did he have this complaint and why didn't he share it with the committee, because they were only given two hours to look at the complaint. So, obviously, it's political. And, you know, Democrats are doing this to set up the president. The reason why Bill Barr is mentioned in the complaint is, obviously, tactical to try to take him out so he cannot defend the president, just like Jeff Sessions could not defend the president against the Russia probe. And it's very tactical in what was said and what was laid out. And the question for Republicans, you know, there's a lot of fodder for them here, too, the dozens -- half a dozen U.S. officials that are named in the complaint. Well, who are those people? Can they bring them up and say why didn't you file a whistleblower report if this was that important? And also, who's behind the writing of the complaint? This is not just an email that someone sent as a, hey, I have information, I need to meet with you. It's very clearly written by a lawyer, or a team of lawyers, and possibly a research team.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I bet it can be traced, ultimately. And I'm not accusing them, but a group like Media Matters is in here with their dirty hands --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: One thing I want to say, though, the mistake the president made was having Rudy Giuliani, his personal lawyer, go doing state business. Why didn't the president make Rudy Giuliani a special presidential envoy? We have presidential envoys. We have one for hostage negotiations. We have several different special -- so then he has -- he has standing --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Special envoy for what?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Special envoy to find out whether or not there was American corruption in Ukraine that perverted, you know, U.S. aid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, here's the thing. I don't think conservatives or libertarians should even argue these points because the narrative is orchestrated by the media. This is artificially constructed. I don't know how you cannot see that they've been driving this for three years. And now you look at the ratings, right? We get the ratings every day. All the networks are up. Even by random accident people are watching CNN. I mean, their numbers are going -- nobody watches CNN, now they are. It's not just the airport.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, impeachment is now the business model. It's always been division and conflict. But now impeachment will be the business model for the next six months.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, and it will get them through until Iowa, and then the ratings will be big for the primary.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One thing I remember from doing press work in all those years, it's like, for every reporter is looking to be Woodward and Bernstein.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're always looking for something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bernstein is still looking for that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they took a break for 8 years during the Obama administration.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they're well-rested. Let's put it that way. All right, next on THE FIVE, forget the facts, Democrats racing to impeach Trump by the end of October. Plus, crooked Hillary returns to, guess what, trash Trump.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Welcome back to “The Five.” Democrats appear to be racing toward impeaching President Trump, and now we have a possible timeline according to several reports, Democrats could potentially draft articles of impeachment by the end of October, next month. And now, Hillary Clinton is supporting the move while still complaining about the lost election. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: He has turned American diplomacy into a cheap extortion racket. He's endangered us all by putting his personal and political interests ahead of the interests of the American people. It's like applying for a job and getting 66 million letters of recommendation and losing to a corrupt human tornado.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The best bet, Jesse, for the Democrats, the experts suggest is a fast, focused inquiry of impeachment, but they just subpoenaed three different committee, just subpoenaed Pompeo, the secretary of state, three different committees. So how do you get fast and focused when you have three have committees, you know, wanting to interview the same witness?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, they'll probably screw it up. I know why they want it to be fast because they want to get over with before people start poking holes in it, because it's easy to poke holes and I did it all week and I was frustrated because Juan never listens to me, doesn't listen to the facts. No one listens to the fact. You can't commence anybody of the truth about the story. It's all opinion and it's all been made up and they decided to move forward with it --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Juan is an honorable man and he disagree with you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Of course he is. And I love Juan, OK? But like -- just Juan -- just like the rest of the media and the Democrats will not listen to the other side. They will not listen to the double standards. They will not listen to the hypocrisy. You can't point anything out about the story and be persuasive at all. So at this point you know my opinion -- impeach, libs. Impeach. Get it over with. You guys have wanted to do it from the very beginning. Have at it. You guys -- it's cathartic. They need to get it over with. And then, you know, he'll get reelected and then you impeach him for a second term? Try that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Impeach libs is a great t-shirt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Impeach him.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: This is, you know, a point of view that I think is held by at least a third of the people. Impeach him. He'll get convicted by every Democrat. None of the Republicans in the House. So that's the indictment. And when it comes to the Senate trial, there's no way 20 Republicans are going to vote to convict.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And it only hurts Democrats, so I agree, like, Republicans can sit back and say we're going to fight the lies. We're going to fight Adam Schiff making stuff up, quite literally at the hearing yesterday and putting it into the congressional record. And we will fight back with information and transparency, and the White House will release call transcripts and do everything they can. And we'll see if Mike Pompeo responds to the subpoena. But in terms of --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It'd be unfair.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You guys wants to do this. You've been doing it for a long time. The fast pace of this means they want ruin everyone's Thanksgiving because politics is hard enough without some kind of impeachment, right? But, you know, the subpoena that was issued to Pompeo is a lie. It's an analysis of the call. I mean, they say by pressuring Ukraine and threatening to withhold information and aid. That's not what the phone call says.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I just -- Reuters has a poll, Dana, that says only 37 percent of the American people support impeachment --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: -- that's down from 41 percent a couple of weeks before. Do you think that it is likely that the Democrats have overplayed this hand?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I think that some of them -- they would not admit it publicly, but privately they have buyer's remorse. Think about where we started this week. On Monday, Nancy Pelosi was still like, oh, wait, let's just see, let's be cautious, let's be prudent, and now here we are off to the races. Those poll numbers could shift a little bit mostly because of the -- there's a huge amount of attention, media attention on it. And so, maybe it ticks up a little bit. But I do think your point about the Democrats having all these different committees look at it. So what they really need is one general and they have six lieutenants right now.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's even worse than that, I think, Greg --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I even had a greater point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's give 10 seconds to Dana.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: By all means. By all means.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that one of the reasons they want to rush and get it done is because they know that the Republican will never go for it. But what they want to be able to do is to go into 2020 so that every news article will always say the impeached president. And they'll say he's corrupt. And they just want to get that done. And then, President Trump, though, in addition to all the other reasons, politically could help him. I don't think a lot of legislation was going to get done anyway. And now he'll have a great reason -- great person to blame, or group of people to blame. He'll say the Democrats are the ones that made sure that we didn't get anything done.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But don't you feel a little Dancy, Greg, about, you know, a probe, the president now, you know, wildly searching for the person who engineered this attempted coup, another attempted coup?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, it's interesting, I think the best part about this is the media and Democrats thinking that Trump isn't going to fight this in front of the public. They're making the same mistake they did in 2015. None of the candidates are going to be able to shine because thanks to the media, Trump is going to suck all the oxygen out of the room. He's going - - they'll be -- look like ant hills and he'll be, you know, Mount St. Helens, because all they'll gonna talk about him is 24/7. And he's going to have some great lines. He's going to go after everyone. And then they'll be the pendulum swing. If they try to undo an election you're going to red pill a country. Can I make a point about Hillary talking about putting the personal in front of the political? I think there was a phone call her husband had that was slightly more troubling than this one if you remember.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Was it on the tarmac? Or is that a meeting on a tarmac, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I was thinking about -- when he was on the phone and something was happening to him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was a service call.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Also, who is Donald Trump going to be talking about and running against for the next six months? It's going to be Nadler --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And Schiff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- Schiff, Maxine Waters. These are not popular Democrats, and it's going to suffocate all the real candidates.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And instead of the candidate's faces being on, you're going to see those people who are very marginal --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And the Trump campaign has already said they have 50,000 new supporters in the last --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And they've raised a ton of money.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yeah. So good luck, Democrats.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Coming up, how the woke media took down the college football fan who raised over a million dollars for charity.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right. Well, cancel culture strikes again, college football fan, Carson King, grabbed headlines after his plea for beer money went viral. He's raised almost $2 million, but instead of keeping it, he decided to donate it all to a children's hospital. Carson was widely praised and even got a beer sponsorship, but now that's all gone. Anheuser-Busch is cutting ties after they launched personalized beer cans with pictures of his face all because reporters dug up offensive tweets from when he was 16, which Carson has apologized for. The Des Moines Register came under fire for reporting on the old tweets. And in a crazy twist, the paper announced the reporter who wrote the story no longer works there after his own offensive tweets were discovered by online investigators. So, Greg, you can hardly contain yourself over this dog-eat-dog world we're in now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean, I'm a complete believer in forgiveness. And if helping sick and dying children can't erase an ugly tweet when you were a teen then nothing can. We're all screwed. The difference between a 16-year-old now and a 16-year-old pre-internet is that today's stupidity is public and it's permanent. We're all very lucky. We all did stupid crazy things. The reporter getting -- losing his job, it shows that this is mutually assured destruction, right? And we need mutually assured forgiveness because we will, in the future, like we do this on the show when like Joy Behar does something stupid or Bill Maher says something stupid, we don't ask for scalps. We say -- I accept the apology. Except, every apology -- and it's a selfish thing, too, because you're hoping they'll accept your apology even though you know that they won't. Their entire organization is bent on rejecting anything Fox does, even if we're sorry about something. They'll destroy you. I will forgive everybody and anybody but you won't get it back, but you still got to do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you do it selfishly. I do it genuinely.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So true.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Social media is like a tattoo.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a good point.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's going to be forever. To get it removed is extremely difficult. It has a downside on your life --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Put a tattoo over it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And you've got to -- as the father of five, that's one of the prime lessons. You know, my eldest is 40, so he was the first of the social media generation, and they learned the hard way that what you put on that thing, you send pictures of yourself here, there, and everywhere --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Geraldo, you're to talk.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I want to feel institutive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's even worse.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. This is family hour. So, Jesse, should you be -- if you knew you said something that was stupid or racist when you were 16 years old, or even as an adult, should you be tarred for the rest of your career if you haven't -- if you apologized sincerely and you're trying to move on with your life. Like, should one thing devastate everything that you have going on for the rest of your future?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think cancel culture is important. I don't think we should totally discard it. I'd like to save cancel culture here in case I need to deploy it strategically on certain enemies that I will use it unforgivingly. But --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: At least he's honest.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I am honest. And I don't forgive people selfishly. I honestly think people deserve forgiveness because I would never say anything that I feel like that would ever cause me harm professionally or personally.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: For to apologize for?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Or that I need to apologize for, because apology -- that shows weakness, Katie. You never want to show weakness unless you really have to, and people tell you have to apologize.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You veer from morality to immorality in one single thought.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Listen, let's face some flexibility, Greg.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Should Trump apologize for asking to look into the background of Joe Biden?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, because in that sense I think he needs to as the commander- in-chief. He needs to know if there's any corruption going on throughout the world and he has every right. In fact, it's his duty to find out if high ranking public official has committed a crime.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And she's also said awful things online.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And he's also said terrible things about Jasper, right? So --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: How do you feel about young people on the internet?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I do stress caution, right? And my niece -- I'm not going to name her because she's a very private person. I think I had like the scared straight program with her when she was very young, and she thought she wanted to go into intelligence and CIA-type work. And I told her, I said, you know, you have to be very careful about social media. Like, she doesn't even have social media accounts. She has never posted anything. I don't know if she -- she's not going to have any photographs of herself anywhere. The media's own goal on this was pretty interesting. The Des Moines Register, the comment section was just like how could you do this to this guy? And interesting thing about Anheuser-Busch, and all of these companies that -- you know, they were like -- they probably had a communications person said, hey, this guy is like raising money for children's hospital. We should get on board. This is really cool. Like, we would get some good P.R. out of it, and they did. And then, instead of saying, look -- imagine this as a corporate leader, if you were to say everyone makes mistakes. He apologized. We've just raised all this money for children's hospital. Let's all do this -- like, let's do this together. That would be really great corporate leadership. Instead, they got so risk averse that they're -- OK, wait, no, we're out. We're out.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They are going to donate the money. However --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And in contrast, the governor --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What those kid tweeted anything.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the governor, she actually had a lot of risk tolerance because they have the day of Carson was today and instead of canceling it, she said no, he did an amazing thing and we're going to celebrate you.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Before you portray him as an angel, I mean the N-word is unforgivable.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm not saying that--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, should his life be destroyed?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I mean comparing humans to animals, it's just - I think that--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Obviously, I don't condone that.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Permanently disqualified.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But here's the thing--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really to a six-year-old kid. That kid's life is over. Maybe just kill him.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Do something else.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like what.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He should do something else besides helping sick kids.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Let him help sick kids.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what he was doing.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's what he was doing.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But he doesn't have to have his face on a beer can. You know--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what's oddly--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The business has the right to do it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Guess what's oddly encouraging, I'm going to bring this up, because I know it's close to your heart. Justin Trudeau. Three times.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I like him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Black face. And that story went away. That story went away.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: He should be canceled; he should definitely not be the leader of the country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did he get canceled?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Black face is different than the N-word.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Particular if you're a fellow or what was he, Arabian Nights. I mean it's not the best thing to do. Don't try it at home.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't try.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Or in Canada.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't try it anywhere maybe.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Only try at home.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Barely you can try in Canada.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I suggest you don't do that. All right. The Fastest 7 is up next. We'll be back.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Time for the Fastest 7. First up, you'll never have to sit next to a crying baby ever again if you take your flight on Japan Airlines is now offering a seating map showing you precisely where all the young children will be sitting. You just got back from Japan. Did you sit next to any children?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I was in business. You know I had an idea for an all baby airlines. It's called JetPoo. And you just stack them up like a little like boxes and the little nannies. And then we don't have to worry about it. Then they just kind of fly over the cities and they have little parachutes and they just dropped a little baby into the village, where it's caught by fair maidens.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Should I keep going with you or go on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'll sit next to a baby if he has Bose headphones and Xanax, doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: See, I like the randomness of it. I like to have people that actually deserve the bad karma of sitting next to a crying baby.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Get it. I don't have bad karma. I have good karma because I sit next to crying babies and I don't mind, because I have children and I've been through that experience bringing young kids on a flight is a terrible experience when your baby cries. So, I understand it. I'm very sympathetic, Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Geraldo, you travel a lot.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I'm a multi-million mile frequent flyer and the luck of the draw. You've got to go rid the punches.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Katie, would you ever look at the map and decide not to sit by the child. I mean if you're given the option.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I'm going to say, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People out there too. Maybe they--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's why you have to bring a mask on the plane.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Taking up two seats. I mean that's the one you don't want to--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, you don't have to fight over your elbow room with a baby, right, they don't have elbows yet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have to fight over room with anyone?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow. Dana Perino.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Feet touched the floor.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Next, UCLA is opening up a new kindness Institute after receiving nearly $20 million from a wealthy couple. It will teach students how to show respect and empathy which the donors say is scarce, so now schools have to teach which used to be taught in the home. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know what I think is kind maybe giving the 20 million to poor people. Why waste it on a stupid study at UCLA. The kind thing to do is give it to people that need the money.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I disagree. I disagree. I agree with this if they're actually talking about connecting people and not separating them through some intersectionality, because this could be like a totally phony thing where you are now indoctrinated into understanding how different you are from other people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When in fact it would be great if they stressed the similarities, which is what we used to do, which is what empathy is, is to be able to identify and feel - identify with others. But we live--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's so--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What Geraldo. What is the--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I mean, empathy is something that is almost instinctive. I don't think you can teach it. You know what I thought of when I heard about the kindness Institute was did someone cheat to get their kid in the kindness institute. Those are things like--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's an interesting thing. You've got to be suspicious even at the kind people.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Right, the kind people sneaking in.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I used to think this is stupid. But you know what, with the day and age, you probably need some more respect to help - the retired Navy SEALs are teaching about respect.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's the point.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And leadership.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The proper people are talking about what that means and maybe a little forgiveness in addition to the empathy--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This could be a recipe for disaster.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, you don't want the typical academics teaching this. You want people that--

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's going to break down on racial lines and you know what groups--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what the academics.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The kindness, you'll be that kindness black guy and you'll be the kindness white girl.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That everyone should be blindfolded, and you shouldn't be able to bring your phone.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I had that rule in my bedroom.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Finally, say what again, I double dare you. Those are just some of the classic Samuel L. Jackson movie lines. You could be hearing soon on your Amazon Alexa devices.

utterances.speaker: SAMUEL JACKSON, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: Today in Los Angeles, it's 85 degrees. Say my name. Aren't we organized?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Not bad for a rookie.

utterances.speaker: JACKSON
utterances.utterance: Say rookie again. I dare you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jackson will be the first celebrity voice for Alexa. I unplug my Alexa. I was a little nervous about the recording.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Of course, and they're snooping on you. They are. I mean--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean they say it's just so that they can improve so that your voice prompts will be more accurate in their responses. RIVERA: But what about just people snooping on you. I mean really just listening in because they can hack your passcode or--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are you worried about that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't use Alexa because I know what records everything and I say a lot of strange things when I'm asleep. I have night terrors. Some of the stuff not good for 5 o'clock. Also, I've had enough of celebrities in my life anyway, I don't need them in my house. It's a pernicious influence. I myself as a world class celebrity do not want to put myself in other people's homes unless they really wish to.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Samuel Jackson would have you for a snack.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know how you can do that. Have you guys heard of this thing called cameo where like you can go, and you can get paid to deliver some birthday message or voice recording or something like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Have you seen the celebrities they use.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and I'm waiting for the celebrity's stature to rise, so I can get on there. I'm not ready to jump in yet, but I'm so excited about the business opportunity.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But who do they have, it's amazing, the people they have its kind of tragic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They have like Screech.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Scaramucci, right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is he on it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I thought he was.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, if he's on it, I've got to be on it. How much can he charge.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I haven't heard from Scaramucci about the Ukraine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well that's Katie on Alexa--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Alexa and Google pod or whatever it is, is a little Google thing is like Alexa. Like throw them all away and burn them all.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Because they're so creepy and the Chinese are listening to everything that's in there and the FBI is using them now in cases and so are the cops. Like I just don't need it. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Well--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: If you're putting it--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Seven minutes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Burn it all. Burn them all.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Don't go anywhere. Fan Mail Friday is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Fan Mail Friday. Let's get to your questions. OK, first question. Not from you again. All right. If your name was a product what would that product be and why? All right, Jesse. I think you've thought about this on your own.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hair Force One.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You like that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's pretty good. Why though?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because of the hair, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It would be a big powerful sailboat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, but it has to be a name of a product.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's it. That's it. The Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Geraldo. Just be a sailboat.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: A big fat sailboat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Riviera.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: This is a hard question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is a hard question. Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I want to say a cowgirl boot. Because you can walk through a lot of stuff with it. And I want to--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Lot of stuff. Thank you. Careful Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Bad word. For the record, it said chucking, not the other bad word.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I beg to differ.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nice spin.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I just clarify for the record.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The jury is still, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Fact checking this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think you're ducking lying. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm going to go with like a dog leash.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A dog leash.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sort of like, the Dana.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Dana, dog - that's a great idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The deash. No, it's not, it's like a leash, but--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's for a dog, Jesse. I'm going to go - the Greg would obviously be a wine opener. Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well that makes sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's like a little one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why would it be a little one.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Are you a wine?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Haiti 2010, why do I need to name them. What kind of car did you drive in high school? What was yours?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Dodge Turismo.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. That says Dana Perino. That says Dana Perino all over the Turismo. Practical, good mileage. Seat belts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It must have been cheap.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: 1947 Chevy convertible. It was like new. I actually got it for $37. My dad spotted me the money of my first car. Take the hood off. See the engine, I was in the valve grinders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Interesting.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I drove a blue Jeep Wrangler.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: My brother's Jeep, she made that very clear and we would blast the Beach Boys, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: In the jeep and get mud in the tires.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Beach Boys were huge last night at the Points of Light event.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Huge, have they put on a lot of weight?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, actually they look very trip. Very trip. I noticed that very, very trip.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, they watch their weight. Anyway.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: East Coast girls.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Stop it, Geraldo. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I had a mustard yellow 1980 Chrysler Baron. Yes, for $500.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I don't even know what that is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Got you around.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow. I had a 76 cut less Supreme and it was like that burgundy color. Remember they had the velvet interior and--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did they have any cigarette burns in--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I was just going to say it and it just stunk like a pack of Lucky Strikes. Lot of stuff happened in that car. A lot of it alone unfortunately. Another question from you. What do you keep on your desk at work that boosts your mood?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Mini me. It's a little replica of myself, like a little bobblehead. Every time I see it, I feel great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's funny, because I have a giant me on my shelf. It's the same size. Thank you very much. Dana you must have something.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, you know you've got your pictures of your family, pictures of Jasper.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Photographs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. Fair enough. Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: My desk has a glass top and under it are all the challenge coins. I got all the different military--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a good place.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I thought you're going to say scotch.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No, I have that in my office too. I had the only bar in the building except for Rupert Murdoch's, but they took it out when I got my new office. Although I still have the booze secreted away there. But I looked at the coins and I remember why we're doing in Iraq or Afghanistan or wherever it's very--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's have a drink after the show, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Yes, man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Katie, do you have a desk here and what you have on it?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The desk that I do have back in D.C. has a box or a cup of gel pens which makes me very happy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I love those.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But something more sentimental is I have a framed piece of the Berlin Wall with Ronald Reagan's tear down this wall speech.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's cool. Very cool.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That makes me happy, because freedom.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Makes everyone happy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I just have--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Gel pens too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have swank. I mean I have my pen. I call it swank. I have a pack. I have a giant case of Sharpies and I throw them out. The moment they get slight - they have to be as rich when you're doing that and if they get this slight drag, I throw them away.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You've got to roll with that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't even give them to charity, Dana. I just chuck them because that's - I live for today.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You chuck them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Watch your mouth.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I chuck them. What career or job doesn't exist, but should? Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's the question. What career or job doesn't exist, but should?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I got one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, go for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think there should just be people that go around and pick up litter.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They have that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not in New York.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Ocean rescue or whatever it is they get. They go around the world getting plastic bottles and so forth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, well maybe here in the state.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I think that all of the calamity stuff about climate change doesn't recognize the fact that the human race is very innovative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very helpful.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Very conscientious when motivated. And I think the environment is going to end up just fine. GUTFELD: Do you guys agree that this question sucks and that we should go to tease.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I just think there's a job for everything which is good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to hear what Dana thinks about--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You might not get paid for it though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The job that doesn't exist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The job that doesn't exist. I don't know. I was just thinking like, I think you need a mentor that you could call on the phone all the time. Right. You don't need a kindness institute people like and advice helpline. I guess that exist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A shrink.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: An advice helpline.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: If you pay for it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what I call that. I call that a friend, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's been a long week.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I call that a friend.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I've been on air - I'm out of words.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't know what you're talking about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Completely out of words.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. On that note, One More Thing is up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, time now for One More Thing. Big game for the Eagles last night. Amazing, amazing game. Actually, they beat the Packers, lot of scorers here, I had a great night.
